background: The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow troutOncorhynchusmykissand ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on theColvilleConfederated Tribes (CCT) reservation (LeCaireandPeone1991). The goal was to restore healthy andharvestablesalmonidpopulations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committees Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy.We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning forsalmonids(Lichatowichet al. 1995;Lestelleet al. 1996;Mobrandet al. 1997;Mobrandet al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Many of the Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow; however, the discharge data is limited for most reservation streams withoutanadromousfish, particularly in smaller streams.While status and trends monitoring is not currently anLRHIPobjective, we wanted to collect baseline information on the stream discharge in a manner that would allow for future monitoring. With the future monitoring option in mind, we developed our protocol so that it was consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (Bouweset al. 2011) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) (TerraquaInc. 2009).
title: LRHIP- Sanpoil and Upper Columbia Subbasin Discharge Point Monitoring
assumptions: Sample sizes are large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings.
objectives: Provide baseline discharge data sets for use in EDT model development.
Describe stream discharge for use in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
